1040861604077.summary: Speaker Dr Lise Jaillant Reader (Associate Professor) in Digital Cultural Heritage at Loughborough University; Visiting Fellow, Wolfson College, University of Cambridge; Cambridge Digital Humanities Associate Lise has a background in publishing history and digital humanities. She is an expert on born-digital archives and the issues of preservation and access to these archives. Since 2020, she has been UK PI for four AHRC-funded projects on Archives and Artificial Intelligence. These international projects aim to make digitised and born-digital archives more accessible to researchers, and to use innovative research methods such as AI to analyse archival data. Lise enjoys working across sectors and disciplines. As a digital humanist, she has extensive experience of collaborating with computer scientists, archivists, librarians, and government professionals to unlock digital archival data with innovative technologies. Abstract This talk presents ground-breaking new work on AI applied to the government records of the Cabinet Office, in order to automatically identify historically significant records to preserve and other records that can be deleted. The Cabinet Office is the UK central government department that supports the Prime Minister in the effective running of government. Its records are among the most important that are deposited in The National Archives, covering those of the Prime Minister, Cabinet proceedings, government efficiency and reform, and the formulation of legislation, among other areas. This talk, which is based on a co-authored article with David Canning (Cabinet Office), does not only describe a radically new methodology to appraise digital records, it also makes a significant theoretical contribution to academic disciplines that seldom talk to each other including archival studies, digital humanities and computer/data science. It proposes a new archival mindset that reflects the digital realities faced by records managers, archivists and users. This theoretical approach combines distant viewing (necessary to approach huge amounts of records) and close reading of a selection of records (to ensure the effectiveness of computational approaches). This combination of distant and close is an answer to the need to move away from paper minds, and embrace digital archival realities and methodologies. The conclusion explores where records management might go next in deploying Artificial Intelligence technologies and the benefits these may have in opening up archives for future historians. Recommendations are offered to facilitate the ethical application of AI to records and archives, in the government sector and beyond. Access If you have specific accessibility needs for this event please get in touch . We will do our best to accommodate any requests.
1040861604077.description: AI to Review Government Records: New Work to Unlock Historically Significant Digital Records
1040861604077.title: AI to Review Government Records | Dr Lise Jaillant

927900564567.summary: Law has been a stable reality of human life in myriad forms for its role in society. Additionally, the category of law is dynamic and overlaps in its imagination, construction, and operation. These transformations have highlighted various sites of conflict, challenges, convergences, and agreements. Join us for the 16th Annual SOAS School of Law PhD Colloquium 2024 to hear from brilliant PhD researchers tackling and unpacking these complex dynamics, formations, and law transformations in a globalized world. Legal systems, practices, and theories are continually in flux, responding to and shaping the complexities of contemporary society at various junctures. It's a fantastic opportunity for PhD students and academics to share their research ideas, engage in lively discussions, attend thought-provoking presentations, and connect with fellow scholars. This year's contributions include topics on: Crisis within International Law and Human Rights Guarantees Transnational Legal Systems Confronting Questions raised by TWAIL Ecological Law and Harmony with Nature: Perspectives on Climate Change, possible Approaches and Challenges AI and Digital Technologies: Challenges to Equality Contemporary Legal Thought and Their Impact on the Transformations of Law and Developing Jurisprudence Costs of Convergence in Constitutional Law: Subaltern Movements and Approaches to Legal Remedies To join via Zoom, please register here: https://soas-ac-uk.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN__hJDxUv0Q8i-PWo4NIJtLA Contact : phdcolloquium@soas.ac.uk
927900564567.description: 16th Annual SOAS Law PhD Colloquium: "Law in Transformation"
927900564567.event_address: 10 Thornhaugh Street Senate House Wolfson Lecture Theatre, London, WC1H 0XG
927900564567.venue_name: SOAS University of London, Thornhaugh Street, London, UK
927900564567.title: 16th Annual SOAS Law PhD Colloquium 2024: "Law in Transformation"

The event will feature presentations from both the Symplectic Team and the Figshare Team focusing on open research infrastructure and management, funding workflows, funder policy compliance, open data, non-traditional research outputs and more. We are aiming to release a preliminary schedule in the next couple of months, but you can expect presentations on the themes above as well as product development-focused presentations from both Figshare and Symplectic. Our agenda Day One (arrivals from 9.30) Figshare: Emerging use cases, integrated research management workflows and open research 10:00 Housekeeping, Welcome & Agenda 10:15 Figshare: Highlights from Recent Releases and Product Roadmap 10:15 [Concurrent session] A Newcomers Introduction to Figshare 10:45 Enhancing the Figshare Review Workflow 11:05 Break 11:35 Figshare at Kings College London: Meeting the different needs of our research community 11:50 Case Study: University of the Arts London (From Outdated to Outstanding: The Piaggi Hat Collections Journey to Figshare) 12:05 Sneak Preview: The State of Open Data 2024 12:35 Case Study: drUM - Data repository of the University of Malta 12:50 Case Study: Charting a Roadmap towards FAIR Data & Software at the University of Sheffield 13:05 Lunch 14:00 Case Study: Carnegie Mellon University (A View from North America - Figshare as an Institutional Repository) 14:20 Unlocking Open Access: Figshare & Symplectic Elements 14:40 Case Study: Implementing Figshare and Elements Together at Karolinska University 14:55 Automatically Populating Figshare Profiles from Elements 15:10 Break 15:40 Interactive Session: Themed Tabletop Discussions 16:40 Day One Wrap-up 16:45 Networking Drinks at the Marquis Cornwallis Please note that you are welcome to attend networking drinks even if you are attending Day Two only. Day Two Symplectic Elements: Research Information, Impact and Institutional Success 09:00 Housekeeping, Welcome & Agenda 09:05 Symplectic Elements: Highlights from Recent Releases and Product Roadmap 09:05 [Concurrent Session] A Newcomers Introduction to Elements 09:35 Case Study: Carnegie Mellon University (A View from North America: Innovation using Symplectic Elements) 09:55 Case Study: Sheffield Hallam University (Using Professional Activities to Support Narrative CVs, Research Planning, REF PCE and PDRs) 10:05 Understanding How Research Happens: How to Begin Tracking Projects with Elements 10:25 Break 10:45 Introducing Awards Management in Symplectic Elements 11:15 Case Study: University College Dublin (From Opportunity to Award: Optimising the Research Project Lifecycle with Awards Management) 11:25 Enhancing the Public Profiles Experience 11:45 Case Study: University College London (UCL Change Builders - Launching Public Profiles) 12:00 New Enhancements to the Open Access Monitor 12:20 Lunch 13:20 Managing External Organisations 13:35 Update on New Navigation 13:45 Showcasing Your Organisations: Introducing Groups to Public Profiles 14:10 Break 14:30 Digital Science Strategic Update: SDGs 14:50 Interactive Panel: Embedding Research Impact (Including Progress Report from the UK Symplectic Elements Research Impact Working Group) 15:10 A new Workflow for Reviewing Outputs & Activities 15:30 Digital Science Strategic Update: REF 2029 15:45 REF Community Discussion and Q&A 16:45 Closing Remarks Please note: If you choose not to attend our REF-related afternoon events, you are welcome to depart early. 1011133305937.summary: Join the African Leadership Organization at the UK-Africa Partnerships Forum on the 21st of November 2024 at the House of Lords, UK . The forum will bring together top policymakers, industry leaders, and visionaries from across the UK and Africa to explore and harness the continent's burgeoning potential. The UK has maintained a long-standing relationship with Africa, historically focused on trade, investment, and development aid. However, the UK's exit from the European Union has prompted a rethinking of its foreign economic policies, particularly toward Africaa continent poised for significant economic growth. In 2023, Africa was seen as one of the fastest-growing regions in the world, with a collective GDP of over $3 trillion. Despite global economic challenges, Sub-Saharan Africa's economy grew by an estimated 3.6% in 2023, with projections to reach around 4.1% by 2024 due to robust performance in key sectors like agriculture, energy, and telecommunications. The UK has responded by recalibrating its relationships through bilateral agreements. In 2021, the UK signed Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) with countries like Kenya, Ghana, and the Southern African Customs Union, ensuring continuity in trade post-Brexit. By 2023, UK-Africa trade was valued at approximately 40 billion, with major exports including machinery, pharmaceuticals, and financial services. However, there is untapped potential to expand trade beyond traditional sectors and drive innovation-led growth across both economies. Though trade between the UK and Africa continues to grow, there is still significant room for expansion. Relatedly, Africa accounts for about 2.5% of total UK exports, and UK Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in Africa reached 50 billion by 2023, largely concentrated in extractive industries, financial services, and infrastructure. The African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA), which came into effect in 2021, and covers 54 African nations with a combined market of over 1.3 billion people, represents a transformative opportunity for UK businesses to access new markets and diversify trade relationships. In 2023, the AfCFTA's potential to boost intra-African trade by 52.3% by 2025 and increase trade with external partners like the UK presents enormous opportunities for collaboration. However, Africa still faces significant challenges in infrastructure development, trade facilitation, and financial inclusion, areas where UK expertise could play a pivotal role. One of the main challenges to expanding UK-Africa partnerships is the need for better policy alignment and regulatory cooperation. Africas regulatory landscape is complex, with varying rules on investment, trade, and digital services across the continent. The UK, through its Department for International Trade and Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO), has been working on developing more harmonized trade and investment frameworks with African governments. The UK-Africa Partnership Forum would therefore create a platform for advancing mutual interests and unlocking new opportunities in trade, innovation, and sustainable development. The event will build upon the strong foundation of existing trade, investment, and development relationships between the UK and Africa, reinforcing established partnerships while identifying areas for expansion and deepening engagement, facilitating discussions and interactions that uncover and develop new avenues for collaboration, as well as influence the future trajectory of UK-Africa relations through high-level dialogue and strategic partnerships, ensuring that both regions benefit from shared prosperity and development. Key Highlights of the Forum 1) Keynote Addresses & High-Level Thematic Panel Discussions 2) Bilateral Meetings, Policy Alignment Discussions & Exclusive Networking Sessions 3) Workshops and Breakout Sessions 4) Exhibition and Showcase (Countries and States Governments Investment Showcase) 5) Unveiling of the African Leadership Magazines special publications
1011133305937.description: THEME: Deepening UK Africa Partnerships in Trade, Innovation, and Development
1011133305937.title: UK-AFRICA PARTNERSHIPS FORUM 2024

944879298417.summary: ICITM has been an annual event. The ICITM 2025 Conference will build on the success of the previous conferences.We welcome you to attend 2025 the 13th International Conference on Industrial Technology and Management that to be held in Cambridge, UK during March 26-28, 2025. ICITM Conferences look for significant contributions to all major fields of the Industrial Technology and Management in the oretical and practical aspects. The aim of the conference is to provide a platform to the researchers and practitioners from both academia as well as industry to meet and share cutting-edge development in the field. It will provide an excellent international forum for sharing knowledge and results in theory, methodology and applications of Industrial Technology and Management. Call for paper: Topics of interest include, but are not limited to: Track 1: Industrial Automation, Communication, Networking and Informatics Track 2: Control Systems, Robotics and Mechatronics Track 3: Electrical Machines and Drives Track 4: Power Electronics and Renewable Energy Conversion Track 5: Power Systems and Smart Grids Track 6: Sensors, Actuators and MicroNanotechnology Track 7: Cloud Computing, Big Data and Software Engineering Track 8: Electronic Systems on Chip and Embedded Control Track 9: Signal and Image Processing and Computational Intelligence Track 10: Production Management Track 11: Advanced Production Management Methodologies Track 12: Project Management Track 13: Research and Development Track 14: Quantitative Analysis in Industrial Management Track 15: Artificial Intelligence and Information Technology in Industrial Management Track 16: Practice and Experiences in Industrial Management Track 17: Digital Factory Track 18: Energy and Environment Management For details about topics, please visit at http://www.icitm.org/cfp.html Publication: Accepted papers with proper registration and presentation will be published in below listed journals collection. Papers will be sent for indexing services. IJEETC: International Journal of Electrical and Electronic Engineering & Telecommunications. Indexing: Scopus (since 2017), Google Scholar, Crossref, etc. IJMERR: International Journal of Mechanical Engineering and Robotics Research. Indexing: Scopus, CNKI, Google Scholar, Crossref, etc. JAIT: Journal of Advances in Information Technology. Indexing: ESCI (Web of Science), Scopus, CNKI, etc. IJIMT: International Journal of Innovation, Management and Technology. Indexing: Google Scholar, CNKI, Ulrich's Periodicals Directory, Crossref, Electronic Journals Library. JOAMS: Journal of Advanced Management Science. Indexing: CNKI, Google Scholar, Crossref. Submission: Full submission should be at least 4 full pages, and within 12 pages. Official language is English in paper writing and presenting. Paper/Abstract for oral presentation only must be submitted with abstract, too. Submission System: https://www.zmeeting.org/submission/icitm2025 Paper Template: https://www.icitm.org/template.doc More details about submission, please via: http://www.icitm.org/sub.html Conference Schedule: Day 1, March 26, 2025 Check in for ICITM 2025 and Conference Material Collection Day 2, March 27, 2025 09:00 18:00 Opening Remarks & Keynote Speech & & Plenary Speech & ICITM Parallel Sessions Day 3, March 28, 2025 09:00 16:45 ICITM Parallel Sessions Cambridge, United Kingdom: Abounding with exquisite architecture, exuding history and tradition, and renowned for its quirky rituals, Cambridge is a university town extraordinaire. The tightly packed core of ancient colleges, the picturesque riverside 'Backs' (college gardens) and the leafy green meadows surrounding the city give it a more tranquil appeal than its historic rival Oxford. Like 'the Other Place', as Oxford is known locally, the buildings here seem unchanged for centuries, and it's possible to wander around the college buildings and experience them as countless prime ministers, poets, writers and scientists have done. Sheer academic achievement seems to permeate the very walls: cyclists loaded down with books negotiate cobbled passageways, students relax on manicured lawns and great minds debate life-changing research in historic pubs. First-time punters zigzag erratically across the river, and those long past their student days wonder what it would have been like to study in such splendid surroundings. Contact: Secretary Assistant: Ms. Eileen Wu E-mail: icitm_icitm@outlook.com

944879298417.title: 13th International Conference on Industrial Technology and Management ICITM

1037884298877.summary: Dr Mark McKenna, Associate Professor in Digital, Tech, Innovation & Business will be joining us from the University of Staffordshire to present findings from his research project: "Levelling Up the Screen Industries - Film and Television Production as Regenerative Strategy in Places Left Behind". He will be sharing case studies from his fieldwork in industry in Southampton, Staffordshire and Sunderland. This is an in-person event, Thursday 28 November 1 - 2 pm, CLC 1.09 (Clerici Building), Headington campus. There is a significant body of work that considers the role of the regions and regionality in the British film and television industry, seen most visibly in Lez Cooke's A Sense of Place: Regional British Television Drama, 1956-82 (2012). The recent devolution of Channel 4, and then the BBC, combined with the investment and growth of areas like MediaCityUK in Salford, Digbeth Loc. Studios in Birmingham, and The Depot in Liverpool, has rekindled interest in the role of the regions in the future of Britains screen economy. However, aside from a few notable exceptions, this work has consistently foregrounded the contribution of larger metropolitan areas, leaving the contribution of smaller city regions underexplored. Without the critical mass and infrastructure of larger city regions, smaller economic areas face a significant disadvantage in fulfilling their potential as locations for the production of film and television content, but that does not mean that attempts are not being made to capitalise on the economic and cultural benefits that a thriving film industry could bring. Taking three regions not typically represented in any discussion of a national film industry, this paper seeks to explore what opportunities exist for places characterised as left behind - areas blighted by what David Etherington, Martin Jones, and Luke Telford termed a structural cocktail of disadvantage including low paid jobs, welfare erosion, indebtedness, destitution, and food insecurity (2022). Taking Sunderland, Stoke-on-Trent and Southampton as its focus, this paper will offer a snapshot of the different strategies that are being employed in three very different regions and will consider their effectiveness against the backdrop of national initiatives like the outgoing governments Levelling Up agenda. Biography : Dr Mark McKenna is an Associate Professor in Film and Media Industries at Staffordshire University. His research is interested in marketing and branding, censorship and regulation, and media labour, and his work has explored these ideas from a range of different perspectives. He is the author of Nasty Business: The Marketing and Distribution of the Video Nasties (EUP, 2020), Snuff (LUP, 2023), and Big Wednesday: Lamenting Lost Youth in the New Hollywood (Routledge, 2024) . He is the co-editor of Horror Franchise Cinema (Routledge, 2021), Stars and Franchises: Identity, Image and Intellectual Property (EUP, 2024) and Screening Controversial Cinema (forthcoming, Routledge, 2025), and the author of the report Silicon Stoke - Developing Film TV and Other Content Production in North Staffordshire , which explored the opportunities that are available locally for stimulating the growth of the screen industries set against the backdrop of the governments levelling-up agenda. This work forms the foundation of McKennas fourth monograph Levelling Up the Screen Industries: Film and Television Production as Regenerative Strategy in Places Left Behind (forthcoming, Routledge)
1037884298877.description: Join Dr. Mark McKenna at Headington Campus to explore how film & TV production can help regenerate 'left behind' regions in the UK.
1037884298877.venue_name: Oxford Brookes University, Headington Campus, Gipsy Lane, Headington, Oxford OX3 0BP
1037884298877.title: Levelling Up the Screen Industries

1029916155947.summary: Be product-centric to get success If you search for Product Management on Google, youll get at least 20 variations on the job title. Spoiler - no one grows up wanting to be a Product Manager....we all get here by accident! Join us for an insightful talk on why Product Management is a vital skill in today's business landscape. Kiran Patel will explore how effective product management drives innovation, aligns teams and creates customer-centric solutions that lead to business growth. Learn how mastering this skill can enhance decision-making, foster collaboration and build products that resonate with market demands, giving companies a competitive edge. Perfect for aspiring product managers, business leaders and entrepreneurs looking to elevate their product strategy. Kiran Patel is a Principal Product Manager at technology and data consultancy Transform UK. After starting off as an Aerospace Engineer, he has spent the last ten years building and managing a range of products/services in a various industries such as Telco, Manufacturing, Automation, Entertainment, Media and Public Sector. Outside of the day job, Kiran loves to run, play and watch football, collecting old vinyl, as well as retro video games - all of this while trying to tame an increasingly energetic 15 month year old who has just figured out how to walk!

857949288417.summary: What they said: I wish I'd had this training years ago! A language for exploring and discussing organisational issues issues that aren't only process-related Found the ideas of context and awareness tied well into managing different relationships This rounds out organisational change aspects any serious practitioner should know Really related to Organising at Human Scale; Energised by the mapping exercises before and after it Previously known as "Leading in a Transforming Organisation" and run in London, Berlin, Melbourne, Manchester, this is three modules of Leading with Outcomes as an integrated, workshop-style training experience: Day 1. Leading with Outcomes: Foundation Day 2. Adaptive Organisation (I): Business agility at every scale Day 3. Adaptive Organisation (II): Between spaces, scopes, and scales We'll be exploring what it means to lead in an organisation where change is happening wherever it's needed, at the pace it's needed, and engaging the people who are needed everyone whose energy, insights, and innovations you'll need. On day 1 (Foundation) we look at how to develop and pursue strategy in the language of outcomes, introducing some key conversational and organisational patterns and tools. You'll be developing skills you can not only bring to set-piece strategy events such as reviews and workshops but apply in everyday settings too. On days 2 and 3 (Adaptive Organisation parts I and II), we will be exercising those skills further as we get to grips with a classic and powerful model of organisation that we've made accessible and brought up to date, applicable to organisations of all shapes and sizes. For any given organisational scale (day 2), what are the preconditions for business agility, and what gets in the way of that? Similarly, in what practical ways can we help the relationships between organisational scales (day 3) to be more healthy and productive? You'll be learning some of the deep magic of organising how to understand it in terms of relationships and constraints and you won't look at organisations in quite the same way again! Audience You can approach Leading in a Transforming Organisation in complementary ways: As a workshop, an opportunity to explore how your organisation (or your client organisation) works and how you might influence that As leadership development, participants invited for their growth potential As technical training, participants attending out of interest in the models covered Per the final section below, as a near-alternative to Leading with Outcomes: Train-the-Trainer / Facilitator If any of those speak to you, you're invited! Venue The event will be held at Barclays Eagle Labs, Southampton, close to Southampton Station and with several hotels within walking distance. Trainer This training will be led by Agendashift founder Mike Burrows , creator of Leading with Outcomes, and four-time (and soon five-time) author: Organizing Conversations: Preparing Groups to Take on Adaptive Challenges (BMI series in Dialogic OD, 2024) Agendashift: Outcome-oriented change and continuous transformation (2nd edition 2021) Right to Left: The digital leader's guide to Lean and Agile (2019, audiobook 2020) Kanban from the Inside (2014) And to come: Wholehearted: Engaging with complexity in the Deliberately Adaptive Organisation (2025) Included free On completion, course participants gain free access to the following for 1 year: Agendashift Academy Subscriber personal access to Leading with Outcomes training in self-paced video form Leading with Outcomes Authorised Facilitator access to workshop materials and the Agendashift assessment tools Upgrade at any time to Leading with Outcomes Authorised Trainer for training materials and the ability to certify training completion and workshop participation. Visit the Agendashift Academy's Store page for further information about these programmes.
857949288417.description: Engaging with complexity in the Deliberately Adaptive Organisation a 21st-century take on a classic model.
857949288417.title: Leading for Innovation in the Knowledge Economy (Southampton)

1012819890557.summary: Introducing D avid Froud David has 25+ years of experience in areas of Information / Data / Cybersecurity, including Regulatory Compliance, Governance Frameworks, Data Protection / Privacy, and FinTech.As Project Lead for several Fortune / FTSE Enterprise Class clients, and many startups. David has performed hundreds of on-site security and compliance assessments for merchants and service providers globally. Currently focused on helping organisations unify their security and data protection programs with regulatory compliance regimes including PCI, GDPR & PSD2. Security is not easy, but it CAN be simple. PCI DSS v4.0 - 'Are You Ready?' A genda 0 9.00 Welcome, tea, coffee, introductions 09.30 Session 1: 'Does the New Standard Makes Sense? Background and Context' Subject : The PCI DSS, a Very Slow Evolution Session Objective: To provide context for the workshop and a little glance into the future. Subject : Is This Where the Standard Should Be? Session Objective: To understand that the PCI DSS is a bare minimum set of controls, and not always appropriate for your business. Subject: Is the Customised Approach Really Such a Radical Change? Session Objective: Understand when, and most especially IF to use the customised approach. 10.30 Break and Refreshments 10.45 Session 2: 'New Reporting and Other Innovations Subject : Reports on Compliance (RoC) are at a Whole New Level Session Objective: QSA companies will inevitably raise their rates. Heres why, and how to prevent it! Subject: Self-Assessment Questionnaires (SAQ) Session Objective: To understand exactly which report youll be filling out. Subject: Overall Impressions and Things to Note Session Objective: To understand that v4.0 is more than just the Customised Approach and new requirements. 12.15 Lunch 13.15 Session 3: New Requirements - Significant Impact Subject: Significant New Requirement What is the True Impact?' Reqs. 3.2.1 / 3.3.2 - Encryption of Pre-Authorisation Data Req. 3.5.1.1 - PAN Hashing Req. 3.5.1.2 - Disk-Level Encryption Subject : Web-Facing Infrastructure Req. 6.4.2 - Removal of Manual Review of Public-Facing Web Applications' Req. 6.4.3 - Management of Payment Page Scripts Req. 11.6.1 - Change-and-Tamper Detection to HTTP Headers Subject: Vulnerability Management / Incident Response Req. 10.4.1.1 - Automated Log Reviews Req. 10.7.2 / .3 - Failure of Critical Security Control Systems Detection and Response Req. 11.3.1.2 - Credentialed Internal Vulnerability Scans 14.45 Break and Refreshments 15.00 Session 4: Other Notables Subject: Enhanced and Targeted Risk Assessments Session Objective : To understand the push towards a far more robust risk management process. Subject: Other New Requirements Session Objective : To understand the remaining new requirements. Subject: So What Now? Session Objective: To understand what to do next. Subject - Discussion, Q&A 17.30 Event close and onto Networking Drinks and Canapes
1012819890557.description: o Why it's the closest PCI Standard yet to how real security should work o Why The 'Customised Approach' future-proofs both the standard and
1012819890557.title: PCI DSS v4.0 - Are You Ready?

1027977377007.summary: All is not well in the central Sahel region of Africa. Since 2011, jihadist insurgencies driven by al-Qaida and IS-affiliated groups have progressively engulfed Mali, Burkina Faso, and Niger. As of 2024, the region has become the worlds new epicentre of jihadist activity, accounting for over half of all deaths from terrorism worldwide. The Sahel is also home to the worlds most neglected humanitarian crises, with over two million internally displaced persons in Burkina Faso alone and thousands killed across the region every year. Capitalising on popular discontent, military juntas have seized and consolidated power in recent years, violently cracking down on dissent and instrumentalising regional and international alliances. Meanwhile, the region has become an unexpected arena of geopolitical competition between global powers vying for influence. As the juntas have distanced themselves from long standing allies such as France and the U.S., Russia has cemented its sway and the presence of its paramilitary forces. After years of worsening violence and political upheaval, the Sahel is now facing a turning point. Jihadist groups are inching ever closer to the regions capitals, violence continues to spiral, and struggling Sahelian juntas face an uncertain future while Moscows shadow continues to loom over the region. *photo credit Finbarr O'Reilly
1027977377007.description: The Sahels spiralling humanitarian and security crises
1027977377007.title: Panel discussion: Volatility in the Sahel

1030094619737.summary: In celebration of the 6th anniversary of the 2018 law change that enabled the prescribing of cannabis medicines in the UK, a series of FREE informative public events will take place this November. Part of Medical Cannabis Awareness Week (MCAW). These events aim to engage with the public, patients, and the wider community, shedding light on the UK's medical cannabis prescription system and the potential benefits of cannabis-based treatments. "An Evening About Medical Cannabis" will be held in three key citiesLondon, Edinburgh, and Cardiff5th to 7th November. Each event will provide attendees with the opportunity to hear from prescribing doctors, patients currently taking medical cannabis, and industry professionals, helping you gain practical knowledge about the UK medical cannabis system and a deeper understanding of the ways in which its prescribed. - London: 6th November 2024 Hosted by Integro Medical Clinics and Alternaleaf, this event will feature talks from prominent cannabis-prescribing medical professionals, including Dr. Sunny Nayee , a pain specialist, and Dr. Anup Mathews , a psychiatrist, alongside special guest Big Narstie, UK rapper and celebrity, who will share his personal experience as a cannabis patient alongside other patient speakers TBC. These events aim to address any questions the public may have about the application, safety, and availability of cannabis-based medicines. Attendees are encouraged to bring along friends and family, especially those who may be skeptical, to gain insight from both medical experts and patients. With an increasing number of people finding relief through these treatments est 50k patients in the UK - the goal is to broaden understanding and encourage open and genuine conversations about cannabis as a medicine, here in the UK. For further information or press inquiries, please contact patients@grow-pharma.com . --- About Medical Cannabis Awareness Week (MCAW) MCAW is an annual initiative that marks the anniversary of the legalisation of cannabis for prescription use in the UK. The week aims to spread awareness about the availability of cannabis-based prescription medicines and to educate the public, patients, and medical professionals about their benefits in treating a range of conditions. These events have been organised collaboratively between UK cannabis-prescribing clinics: Alternaleaf https://www.alternaleaf.co.uk/ Cannabis Clinic Cardiff https://www.cannabiscliniccardiff.co.uk/ Integro Medical Clinics https://www.integroclinics.com/ MaMedica https://mamedica.co.uk/

796778394627.summary: To get your 10% FORS Discount , please email info@fbgtraining.com BEFORE you purchase your ticket. IMPORTANT: When booking a ticket, you must inform info@fbgtraining.com of your full company name, so we can upload the FORS Training successfully to TFL. *LUNCH* Please note: This course includes a light lunch. For dietary / allergy requirements, please contact info@fbgtraining.com (One light lunch per candidate). Registration: Starts at 7.30am It is your responsibility to ensure you plan your journey in advance. If you do not attend there will be no refund of your course fee. If you turn up after the course has started you will be refused entry and any rebooking will be subject to a full rebooking fee. The course includes a practical on-road cycle training element and gives drivers a real life experience as to a cyclists perspective of riding on busy roads, as well as in traffic. The course consists of two 3.5-hour modules (both delivered on the same day); the first module is classroom-based theory and the second module is an outdoor practical session, where delegates are able to get a cyclist view of the road. The FORS Professional Safe Driving course highlights a drivers regulatory responsibilities, the importance of safe driving practices on motorways, rural and urban roads, and other hot topics that can negatively impact safe driving such as driver fitness, health, distraction, and impairment. The course includes a practical on-cycle session and a theory module. Both modules (i.e., the practical and on-cycle sessions) are 3.5 hours each, counting towards seven hours of Driver CPC, plus the mandatory work-related road risk training as required at FORS Silver. Work Related Road Risk (WRRR) Fleet Operator Recognition Scheme (FORS) Silver level Construction Logistics and Community Safety (CLOCS) Standard Please ensure that you dress accordingly. To add, Hi-Vis sleeveless jackets and helmets are provided by FBG Training on the day and must be worn by all delegates at all times throughout the cycle element. This is for your safety. IMPORTANT: Any driver attending the course must have their identity checked by either a photo card driving licence, Operator card or a Driver Qualification Card (DQC). This will allow FBG Training to register the driver onto the Transport for London master SUD database which confirms the driver has attended the course. For a driver to be uploaded to the FORS/TfL register and/or be accredited with the Driver CPC hours they must complete the entire course. Generally, the only reasons for not taking part in the cycle element are on medical grounds, or if during the cycle familiarisation session, the driver is risk assessed as not safe to ride a bike on public roads in these instances it is acceptable for the drivers to walk the course meeting up with the cyclists at the exercise/discussion points and joining in with the discussion. You MUST bring your Driver Qualification Card to ensure you are eligible for Driver CPC periodic training. This course contains content relevant to drivers that hold a vocational category C1, C, CE. The course content is not fully aligned to drivers with a vocational category D1, D, DE. The holder of these categories, however, can attend and gain their 7hrs. IMPORTANT- Have you completed this course before? You cannot attend the same course within a 5-year period unless you have a good reason to repeat it. For more information, contact our office info@fbgtraining.com. Did you know? FORS insist all delegates complete the cycle element in all-weather types to gain your certificate so COME PREPARED. Bring suitable clothing, water and sun cream if applicable for the weather conditions on the day. Refusal to participate in the full course will result in no accreditation. Please note: Travel costs are not included. Refreshment: Tea, Coffee and Light Lunch included. (For dietary and allergy requests, please contact: info@fbgtraining.com at least 1 week prior to the course date.) Parking: All candidates MUST register their vehicle registration at reception upon arrival in order to park on site for free. It is your responsibility to adhere to this stipulation. Failure to do so may result in a car parking charge being issued. Learning Disability: If you have a learning disability and/or require additional support, please contact FBG Training at info@fbgtraining.com to let us know. Own equipment If you prefer to use your own bicycle, you may bring & use it subject to a safety check. You use this at your own risk and security. Farrow Browne and Gryspeerdt Ltd will not be responsible for the safety and security of your equipment or any damage to your equipment that may occur while using the equipment on our course. You MUST inform a member of the admin team at least 48hrs prior to the course date if you wish to bring your own bike. Contact: info@fbgtraining.com *Occasionally images or video footage may be taken on our courses. By purchasing a ticket, you are complying with Farrow Browne Gryspeerdt Ltd's terms and conditions that if images or video footage is taken, it will only be used for marketing purposes on our website or social media pages. (If you do not wish to participate in any imagery or video, it is your responsibility to contact Farrow Browne Gryspeerdt Ltd before your course date.) All bookings are subject to our Cancellation Policy and by registering for a course you are agreeing to its terms. Email info@fbgtraining.com for our cancellation policy.

1013685790487.summary: What do we do when safeguarding makes people less safe? What does safety really mean for young people? NSUN and Act Build Change recently published The Shape of Safety: a guide to reimagining safety and safeguarding alongside young people with lived experience of mental ill-health, distress and trauma. You can find the guide here: https://www.nsun.org.uk/resource/the-shape-of-safety-2024/ Created in collaboration with user-led young peoples organisations Revoke and Voice Collective, this project is the result of a series of workshops centering young people with lived experience of mental ill-health, distress or trauma, who have been failed and disempowered by safeguarding systems. Taking a trauma-informed, anti-oppressive approach, the guide shares and celebrates methods of fostering cultures of safety and care for young people that have been effective. The guide centres lived experience and young peoples agency in offering principles for better practice, reflective questions and a practitioners checklist to support organisational change. Youre invited to join NSUN, Act Build Change, Revoke and Voice Collective to hear about what we learned during this project, and to discuss how to take radical safeguarding approaches within your own work. Were hosting two gatherings, one online and one in person, so you can join wherever youre based theres no need to come to both (unless youd like to). Youre welcome to join us for as long as you can, and step out if need be.
1013685790487.description: Join us at the Launch Event for 'The Shape of Safety', a guide to reimagining safety and safeguarding alongside young people.
1013685790487.title: Launch Event: The Shape of Safety

1040710963507.summary: In this event, Professor Sufian Jusoh will speak about the ASEANs role in fostering unity and solidarity among its member states during geo-economic challenges. The Leaders of ASEAN during the 42nd and 43rd ASEAN Summits in Indonesia in 2023 agreed to work towards an ASEAN Vision 2045, which will replace the current ASEAN Vision 2025: Forging Ahead Together. The ASEAN Vision 2045 is set to shape the destiny of the ASEAN region, which is one of the most economically dynamic economic regions and predicted to collectively be the 4th largest economy in the world. ASEAN faces a lot of challenges and uncertainties in moving towards the next phase of regional integration. Firstly, ASEAN needs to foster unity and solidarity among its member states in facing the regional and global geo-economic challenges. ASEAN has to be able to address the elephants in the room, i.e. the uncertainty in Myanmar, and the more assertive China in its own backyards. ASEAN Member States have also not been able to specifically find common grounds on other conflicts such as in the Middle-East and the Russia-Ukraine, what more with Taiwan facing a much greater threat from China. Secondly, ASEAN will have to address the inclusive growth and economic disparity among its own member states, including Timor-Leste. The economic disparity is further exacerbated by issues like climate change; rapid technology changes where most ASEAN Member States are technology adopters instead of technology frontrunners; competition for resources such as critical minerals, renewable energy, and food security and the uncertain global and regional financial landscape. Finally, ASEAN may have to play an important role in the re-globalisation, where ASEAN as a region plays an important role in re-igniting the multilateral trading system, whilst continuing addressing the regional trade and investment priorities like the full and effective implementation of the RCEP. Most importantly, ASEAN Vision 2045 will be the catalyst for regional and global economic growth, setting the pace for peace, stability and prosperity in this region. This event is being run in collaboration with Malay World Studies, St Catharines College, and will be followed by a drinks reception. Malay World studies events | St Catharines College, Cambridge About the speaker: Professor Sufian Jusoh is the Director and Professor of International Trade and Investment at the Institute of Malaysia and International Studies, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia. He is also an FDI Advisor, ArtNet, UNESCAP, International Investment Policy Consultant at the World Bank Group, External Fellow at the World Trade Institute, University of Bern, Malaysias representative to ERIA RIN and a delegate to the ASEAN High Level Task Force for ASEAN Community Vision Post 2025. In APEC, Sufian played a key role in the success of Malaysias chairmanship of APEC 2020, leading to the APEC Putrajaya Vision 2040, Malaysian representative to the preparation of the APEC Food Security Roadmap 2030, and a delegate to the APEC Investment Expert Group. Sufian plays a key role in the reform of the investment policies in Bangladesh, Malaysia, Laos, Myanmar, Timor-Leste, the Federated States of Micronesia and Pakistan. Sufian is a Barrister-at-Law (England and Wales) of Lincolns Inn, London, and holds an LL.B (Hons.) from Cardiff Law School, LL.M, University College London, and a Doctor of Law from University of Bern, Switzerland.
1040710963507.description: Professor Sufian Jusoh will discuss ASEAN's role in fostering unity and solidarity among its member states during geo-economic challenges
1040710963507.title: Geo-economic challenges in the ASEAN integration towards 2045

912109793947.summary: In this seminar Kim will explore DDP with the help of reflections and dialogues from the Healing Relational Trauma Workbook by Dan Hughes and Kim Golding. This will include providing DDP interventions with the children, building therapeutic alliance with the parents, and also how DDP informed parenting support can help the caregivers to emotionally connect with their children in ways which increase feelings of safety and security. We will explore the impact of developmental trauma on the children and families and consider what is needed to help the children recover and thrive. We will consider the principles central to DDP interventions and how these can inform the support we offer. Central to these will be cultivating the attitude of PACE (playfulness, acceptance, curiosity, and empathy). This exploration will include reflecting on cultural variations in the attitude of PACE and working with families from cultures different to our own. This will provide us with models for DDP in therapy, in parenting and as parenting support in the moment. Objectives and outcomes from the course The learning objectives of the Seminar are: Explore the impact of developmental trauma on the children and families. Consider the principles central to DDP interventions and how these can inform the support we offer. Reflecting on cultural variations in the attitude of PACE and working with families from cultures different to our own. Theoretical and practical considerations Who should attend This day is open to anyone wishing to attend who is working with children and young people. Pre-requisite No pre requisites are required for this course. Additional Info With full attendance you will be issued a certificate of attendance. Fee of 100 includes VAT, registration, buffet lunch and refreshments throughout
912109793947.description: Reflecting on and exploring the Practice of DDP to help children who have experienced developmental trauma
912109793947.title: Healing Relational Trauma with Kim Golding Reflecting on & exploring DDP

1020457033457.summary: Civil society and the civil service often work to a common purpose after all, both are concerned with the civil, namely citizens and their concerns. However, a closer relationship could help enrich both sectors' impact. This unique, cross-sector event aims to develop richer and more powerful connections between the civil service and civil society and set out what potential impact a closer working relationship could have at both a local and national level. Join fellow guests from across the civil service and civil society to: Hear best practice case studies Have your say on the potential structural changes that could enable closer working between the two sectors Learn more about the opportunities for mutual upskilling that already exist. Attend in-person or online Guests are welcome to attend in person or online, but limited space is available to join in person. The event will be held in Westminster. The venue will be communicated closer to the time. Online attendees will gain access to the event app, featuring interactive sessions, workshops, extra content and virtual networking opportunities. Priority will be given to attendees from the civil service or charity sector. If you are from another sector, you may be placed on the waitlist initially due to limited capacity. Thank you. Speakers will include: Abi Miranda, Anna Freud Becky Morrison, Director of Civil Society and Youth Directorate, Department for Culture, Media and Sport Charlotte Hill, CEO, The Felix Project Jane Ide, CEO, ACEVO Joanna Penrose Buckley, Deputy Director Refugee Resettlement & Integration, Home Office Kunle Olulode, Director, Voice4Change Lindsay Cordery-Bruce, CEO, WCVA Marc Rooney, Department for Education Marie Elise Howells, Deputy Director for Volunteering and Tackling Loneliness, Department for Culture, Media and Sport Matt Whittaker, Chief Executive, Pro Bono Economics Ravi Gurumurthy, CEO, Nesta Sarah Elliot, Chief Executive, NCVO Sarah Swash, Deputy Director - Head of National Biodiversity, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Susannah Storey, Permanent Secretary for the Department for Culture, Media and Sport Wanda Wyporska, CEO, Safe Passage International Sessions will include Case studies - The power of successful partnerships Be inspired by real world changes delivered by a partnership between the civil service and civil society through two quick-fire presentations. Speakers will reflect on what makes for good engagement between the two sectors and the potential impact the civil service and civil society can have on peoples lives when collaboration is done right. Pan el discussion - Working closer to achieve more What are the shared challenges facing civil society and the civil service? How can a closer partnership between civil society and the civil service make a difference in addressing them, especially in the context of tight public finances and strained public services? What would a closer relationship between civil society and the civil service look like, what benefits would it bring, and what practical steps could be taken to achieve this? Speakers will address these questions and share ideas for practical, systemic changes that could enrich the working relationship between civil society and the civil service, and so make the most difference to the public. Workshop - Encouraging volunteering Hear from civil servants and civil society leaders on their experiences of volunteering, before breaking into small groups to discuss the following questions and contribute to a resource of recommendations: What can the civil service and civil society do to break down the barriers that prevent more civil servants from volunteering? Civil servants in trustee roles: what value does this bring to civil society and what benefits are there for civil servants? Exploring other volunteering opportunities: assessing their impact and how to raise awareness of different options
1020457033457.description: Register now to hear from senior civil servants and civil society leaders on how to enrich the relationship between the two sectors
1020457033457.title: A Civil Alliance

1044101946027.summary: Please do consider a donation - all kindnesses, small or large, go a long way in helping us deliver our nature outreach programme. The presentation of contemporary art in natural history collections is a distinct field of curatorial practice that also has a recent art and exhibition history. The opportunities that this work presents for museums and audiences alike are manifold, but it is not without challenges. This lecture discusses the production and display of contemporary art in natural history collections across a range of institutions and examines the ways this work has addressed ecological concerns such as species and habitat loss. At a time when museums across the sector are declaring a climate emergency and developing ways to respond, Dr Sarah Wade suggests that this artistic and curatorial work provides productive ways to activate collections, engage audiences and offer new possibilities for thinking through human-wildlife relations in ecologically troubled times. Dr Sarah Wade is Associate Professor in Museum Studies at University of East Anglia. She has published widely on extinction and wildlife conservation issues in artistic and curatorial practice. She also co-founded the Curating the Sea research project, resulting in a special issue of the Journal of Curatorial Studies (2020) and Oceans: Documents of Contemporary Art (MIT Press/Whitechapel Gallery, 2023). Sarah has worked with various museums and heritage organisations and continues to collaborate with museum colleagues on research, exhibitions and public engagement events. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Lead Image: Installation view of Sonia Levy: For the Love of Corals, Obsidian Coast, 2018 . This is an in-person event at the Linnean Society of London on Piccadilly, London. If you have chosen to 'watch a recording', a link to the recording will be sent to you within a week of the event. If you'd like to stay updated about our events programme, and other news, please subscribe to our monthly newsletter here. Terms and Conditions.
1044101946027.description: Considering human-wildlife relations in ecologically troubled times through curatorial practice in natural history collections.
1044101946027.title: Ecologies of Display | Contemporary Art in Natural History Collections

1026735472437.summary: How do practitioners, researchers, and activists get better at driving change in education? A power and systems approach. Drawing on the recently published second edition of his book, Duncan will be sharing lessons for education activists not just in civil society, but in government, the education system and anywhere where people are trying to make the world a better place. He will touch on a bit of theory, but the focus of this seminar will be a practical one. Drawing on his 20 years with Oxfam, on numerous conversations with activists around the world, and the knowledge and ideas in the room, Duncan will share valuable insights on how we can get more intentional about effecting change. How do we move from a better understanding of the problem, to unpacking the power and stakeholders around a given issue, to coming up with a strategy with a decent chance of getting results? Duncan will be signing copies of the new edition of his book after the seminar. If you want to buy a copy, please bring 10 in cash or make sure you have Paypal account details on hand. The book is free online, but then youll miss out on getting it signed.
1026735472437.description: How do practitioners, researchers, and activists get better at driving change in education? A power and systems approach.
1026735472437.venue_name: Faculty of Education, University of Cambridge, Donald McIntyre building, Room GS5 - ground floor.
1026735472437.title: The Role of Coalitions in Transforming Education Systems

1034841919037.summary: "ANYTHING IS POSSIBLE!" - Young Women's Conference with Turtle Dove Cambridge ! Join us for our first Young Women's Conference , designed to connect young women, their communities, businesses, and trailblazing women across industries. This event aims to bridge the gap between young women and the professional world, offering a platform for shared experiences and mutual support. Why attend? Young women today face unprecedented challenges that often hinder their ability to reach their true potential. This conference is a space for inspiring stories of overcoming adversity, achieving success, and navigating the worlds of work, life, and business. Through fostering a supportive, intergenerational community, we aim to provide young women with a voice , a purpose and a choice , and increased confidence to break down barriers. Our mission is to encourage and seek opportunities for young women, aged 14-24, who are at risk of unemployment due to a lack of confidence, experience, or opportunity. This event will offer practical guidance, reassurance, and real-life success stories for young women in Cambridge. What to expect: Keynote speakers Networking opportunities Creative activities Group discussions on how women can support each other in their personal and professional lives. Who should attend? We welcome young women, businesses, particularly women-led and gender-positive organisations, to participate and engage in this vital conversation. It is an opportunity to share your journey, connect with aspiring young women, and open doors for the next generation to thrive in the workforce. This is an opportunity to empower young women with purpose whilst providing businesses with access to an untapped pool of talent and resource, we aime to help bridge workforce gaps and build a more inclusive future for all.
1034841919037.description: Join us for our first Young Womens Conference - Getting Young Women into the Workplace and Business. Anything is Possible
1034841919037.title: Young Women's Conference with Turtle Dove Cambridge

928468703887.summary: Join B4 Members for the next Property Ecosystem as they share challenges, successes and advice with each other in the 2nd of our Property Ecosystem Roundtable discussions hosted at Mills & Reeve LLP with Laura Ludlow, Principal Associate. About the discussion Oxfordshire is a science and technology super-cluster. Its universities, science parks, academics, investors, companies and its thriving advisory community all play a vital part. The region has 2,950 high-tech businesses employing nearly 29,000 people, with the countys knowledge economy contributing 2.4billion to the UK economy every year. The sectors success has an enormous impact on the Oxfordshire real estate market. Continuing strong demand for offices and laboratories is coupled with multiple schemes in construction or at the planning stage. At the Roundtable, we will discuss the significance of this sector on the Oxfordshire real estate market and how the market can support the full ecosystem and life cycle of the science sector. About Laura Ludlow Laura is a real estate development lawyer with an ESG focus. She has substantial experience of a diverse range of commercial property and construction matters, acting for universities and colleges, investment funds, developers, owners and occupiers on the management and development of their estates. Laura has worked at Mills & Reeve in Oxford and Cambridge, after several years working in London. With a keen interest on the ESG impact of real estate, Laura sits on the BPF Sustainability Committee and leads the M&R Real Estate ESG Group. Laura also works closely with IntoUniversity, the charity helping young people access higher education and achieve their aspirations, managing M&Rs team of volunteers supporting their community work. Outside of work, when not running around after her family, youll likely find Laura on the hockey pitch. About Mills & Reeve Yes, Mills & Reeve is a law firm. But we offer much more than just legal know-how. Like a deep understanding of the issues your business faces, based on solid sector and market expertise . Innovative technology and resources you wont find anywhere else. And a culture of continuous improvement. Whatever the size of your organisation from small family-owned businesses to multinational corporations, and everything in between were passionate about helping you succeed. This event is limited to 16 guests Parking: IMPORTANT - There is no parking at Mills & Reeve - We would recommend that attendees use public transport or closest car parks will be Long Stay Oxford Station Car Park OX1 1HS (3 minute walk) or Worcester Street Car Park OX1 2BX (10 minute walk)
928468703887.description: Join B4 for our 2nd Property Ecosystem Roundtable discussion hosted at Mills & Reeve LLP
928468703887.title: Property Ecosystem Roundtable discussion

953301559627.summary: As a financial adviser, you know how important it is to keep up with the latest trends in advicetech and fintech. However, with so many new technologies emerging every day, it can be difficult to know which ones are worth investing in. If you're looking for guidance on how to choose the right technology for your business, you won't want to miss the Empowering Advice Through Technology conference 2025. This one-day event will explore hot topics in the world of advicetech and fintech, offer live demos of cutting-edge technologies, and provide opportunities to meet with software vendors. Empowering Advice Through Technology 2025 is designed with financial advisers in mind. So whether you're a seasoned pro or just starting out, this event is for you. You'll have the chance to sit in on a series of plenary sessions, each one exploring a different area that's essential for advice firms to consider. In addition to the plenary sessions, the event will feature a "battle of the tech" competition, where you'll have the opportunity to see live, fast-paced demos of some of the leading-edge technologies that can help transform advice businesses. This is your chance to see firsthand what's possible with the latest tech tools. Of course, this conference isn't just about seeing what's possible - it's also about finding solutions that work for your business. That's why the event includes an exhibition space where you can meet with a host of software vendors and get personalised advice on which solutions make sense for your business. You never know you might discover a tech tool that you didn't even know existed! Join us at Empowering Advice Through Technology 2025 - you'll walk away with actionable insights and a fresh perspective on how to integrate technology into your practice.
953301559627.description: "Empowering Advice Through Technology" - a one-day conference to help firms understand the issues to consider when choosing technology.

1027861018977.summary: Are you working out how to capitalise your business for growth and expansion in 2025? Do you have an appreciation as to the current funding landscape that may impact your success? Venture capital funding remains below peak levels seen during 2021s boom, as early-stage startups, particularly in speculative sectors, face tougher competition for funds. Many growth companies are opting for mergers and acquisitions, as established companies, especially those with cash reserves, are acquiring smaller firms at discounted valuations, and Private Equity is filling in the Venture Capital hole. Economic conditions have made it hard to raise money from banks, with investment unreadiness and creditworthiness causing hiccups along the way, and companies now look for alternative sources of debt to underpin change. Fusion Consulting Group has brought together an entertaining and knowledgeable panel to bring you fresh ideas and help you navigate the challenging fundraising and M&A environment.
1027861018977.description: FCG has brought together a panel to bring you fresh ideas and help navigate the challenges of fundraising and M&A

1027861018977.title: Forging the Future: Fresh Perspectives on M&A and Fundraising

1007345065207.summary: The UK Agri-Tech Centre's Crop Technology Southern Hub is based at the Agri-Informatics Building at Cranfield University, and delivers academic rigour, data analytics and agri-tech expertise. It is home to world-class collaborative research within state-of-the-art facilities. At this event you will have the opportunity to engage with our dynamic team and discover how you can leverage their expertise to power agri-tech innovation and adoption. Connect with fellow members and build your network, exchange ideas and foster new collaborations to support your agri-tech ambitions. At the UK Agri-Tech Centre we can provide a range of spectral imaging facilities and services from controlled environment automated systems through to farm scale remote sensing. We will showcase some of these systems and discuss how they are important tools for agri-tech product development, especially for AI-based tools. The following items will be on display: Solar-Induced Fluorescence Imaging System: A unique capability, this is an imaging solar-induced fluorescence sensor mounted on a drone platform. This is a compelling alternative to light aircraft or satellite-based deployments and offers a higher spatial resolution and greater deployment flexibility. Ideal for development of disease detection systems. HySpex Mjolnir Hyperspectral sensor: Drone mounted hyperspectral system operating from 400 2500 nm. Useful for a range of developments including disease detection, nutrient mapping and yield forecasting. There will also be an opportunity to view the Plant Phenotyping and Soil Health Facility which demonstrates the cross-rotational, multi-seasonal context from tillage operations, through drilling, plant establishment and crop development, to harvest and post-harvest. This is the world's first glasshouse designed to study plant-soil-water relationships at pilot scale under a multi-sensor phenotyping gantry. This event is open to all - research organisations, agri-businesses, farmers and agronomists - to explore how soil management can impact soil and crop health and protection. This event is free to attend, and will include lunch and refreshments.
1007345065207.description: The UK Agri-Tech Centre invites you to join us on the 15th October for an Agri-Tech Connect event at our Crop Technology Southern Hub.
1007345065207.venue_name: Agri-EPI Centre Crop Technology Southern Innovation Hub
1007345065207.title: Agri-Tech Connect: Crop Technology Southern Hub

970340192637.summary: Convenors: Andrew Moeller (Faculty of History); Alberto Giubilini (Oxford Uehiro Centre for Practical Ethics) With the rapid development of AI and biotechnologies come vast powers to reshape ourselves and the natural world. Whether it is about human-animal chimeras, CRISPR-CAS9, mass automation, or brain-computer interfaces, there exists an urgent need for broad societal discussions to help chart a responsible path forward. As technological advances grant us new powers, so do they blur some boundaries between humans, animals, and machines, prodding us to ask the question: what does it mean to be human? The Biotechnologies, Artificial Intelligence, and Human Identity Conference brings together scholars from across disciplines to assess the right uses of AI and biotechnologies. In the medical and healthcare context, these technologies have the potential to help persons with a wide range of physical disabilities. It is likely that medicine and healthcare will be among the first fields of application of such technologies. But some suggest their use can be extended well beyond therapeutic interventions. Through these technologies, the boundaries between therapies and enhancement become blurred and the power to alter fundamental aspects of human nature and human relationships is increased. For instance, we could potentially control the emotions or physical actions of another person via an implant in our brain and in their own. Or control the pleasure centres in our own brains. It may not also be clear who has primary agency when it comes to a particular act or decision. We might be able to heighten our own alertness and awareness and increase other capacities. And so on. With the potential for what some might consider the misuse of these technologies, how do they challenge traditional views on human nature? And conversely, how proposed, shared aspects of our humanity ought to shape personal, societal, and governmental positions on the right uses of biotechnologies and AI? By considering what it means to be human, we believe we can foster more substantial and productive debates and encourage broader societal involvement in these debates. These are matters for the whole human family, as they relate to our very nature as human beings, as well as our place within the natural order. Free lunch provided for those who registered _______ Eventbrite processes data (including any personal data you may submit by responding to this invitation) outside of the European Economic Area. Please only submit any personal data which you are happy to have processed in this way, and in accordance with Eventbrites privacy policy applicable to attendees (available here: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/support/articles/en_US/Troubleshooting/eventbrite-privacy-policy?lg=en_GB). If you prefer not to use Eventbrite for responding to this invitation, you may respond directly to torch@humanities.ox.ac.uk.
970340192637.description: Part of the Medical Humanities Research Hub's events
970340192637.title: Biotechnologies, Artificial Intelligence, and Human Identity

941947930617.summary: Registration cost: 195 + VAT I Early bird and group booking discounts available | Course open to all genders This course for real estate professionals examines techniques and gives practical advice for moderating successful panel discussions and getting the best out of panellists. The course will teach you how to facilitate an engaging and interesting session for the audience. The course is limited to 8 participants to ensure time for all to practice. The course will cover the following topics: What to expect from moderating an event and how to prepare Key communication techniques required to moderate successfully Understanding and managing your panellists Putting theory into practice with mock panel discussions On completion of the course, attendees will be able to: Understand the role of moderators and how to prepare Effectively facilitate an engaging panel discussion Who should attend the course? This course is open to all real estate professionals. Programme at a glance 08:45 - 09:00 Welcome and breakfast 09:00 - 09:15 Introduction Format of the day Previous moderating experience Issues and areas of focus 09:15-09:45 Moderating: setting up for an engaging panel Roles and responsibilities of the moderator Key communication techniques for moderating Question flows 09:45-10:15 Moderating: successful delivery on the day Dealing with typical panellists How to prepare On the day logistics 10:15 -11:00 Moderating practice with peer review 11:00-11:15 Course ends Who is running the course? Andrea Carpenter, Co-founder and Director, Diversity Talks Real Estate and Women Talk Real Estate Andrea Carpenter is Co-Founder and Director of Diversity Talks Real Estate, and a writer and communications consultant in the property industry. As a Director of Diversity Talks Real Estate, Andrea helps raise the visibility of under-represented groups in the industry through the stage and media. This includes training and other women-led initiatives through DTREs Women Talk Real Estate community. On the writing side, her book about the history of the modern European property industry, High Rise and Fall, was published by Routledge in September 2018. A ndrea regularly moderates industry panel discussions as well as whole events for industry bodies, including ULI Europe Annual Conference and INREV's Annual Conference. Andrea began her career as a journalist at Property Week before moving on to be editor of EuroProperty for seven years. Following this she worked for various industry bodies including the Urban Land Institute, INREV in Amsterdam, and its sister organisation ANREV in Hong Kong. On returning to the UK, she worked as Head of Marketing and Communications EMEA at CBRE Global Investors. Women Talk Real Estate is part of Diversity Talks Real estate, a non-profit organisation dedicated to increasing the visibility of professionals form under-represented groups in the European built environment industry. Our speaker platform connects these professionals with speaking and media opportunities and we provide training for successful stage and media presence. www.womentalkrealestate.org FAQs How can I contact the organiser with any questions? Please contact us on liz@womentalk-re.org What's the refund policy? Moderating a successful panel course is designed for 8 people to ensure the best results and time for all to practice. As such we can offer the following cancellation policy: Delegated can apply for a full refund up to 7 days prior to the event Refunds will not be issued for cancellation requests received less than 7 days prior to the event You can transfer your place free of charge to a colleague/peer at any point whilst the registration is open All cancellations/transfers must be done through Eventbrite and might be subject to Eventbrite cancellation fee

1026764840277.summary: This is not a trade show. We dont like to blow our own trumpets but the Short Term Rental Summit promises to be pretty special. Hosted by the team at ShortTermRentalz.com, its where the leading minds of short-term rentals come together to share their visions for the future and strategies for success. And its also a golden opportunity to network with the investor community as we connect you to the capital and the capital to you. Every area of the short term rental industry is represented a whos who of owners, investors to property managers and tourism boards dont miss it. Join ShortTermRentalz as we host our dynamic Short-Term Rental Summit to London in person in November 2024. Building upon our 24/7 coverage of short-term rentals at the forefront of the impact of technology, platforms, and professionalisation on both the urban and traditional vacation rental sector this event will bring together a wide range of founders, CEOs, investors, and veterans in the industry to discuss the opportunities and challenges ahead. Dont miss out on this forward-looking event, as we explore: Where is the market headed in 2025 and will recession headwinds impact the sector? How are the dynamic needs of blended travellers reshaping expectations and experience? What technologies will transform the way STRs attract travellers and manage operations? What will greater price transparency mean for players both large and small across the sector? How is the relationship with online travel agencies evolving, and what can those platforms do to better serve both owners and travellers? What shifts in real estate will provide growth opportunities for short-term rentals and also hotel brands? What are the crucial elements needed for short-term rentals to evolve as a sector and continue to build trust with consumers? Speakers Piers Brown, CEO, International Hospitality Media Paul Stevens, Editor of Short Term Rentalz, International Hospitality Media Eloise Hanson, editor of hospitality, International Hospitality Media George Sell, editor-in-chief, International Hospitality Media Sally Henry, vice president of business development, EMEA, Key Data Dale Smith, founder and CEO, Host & Stay Alistair Handyside MBE, executive chair, PASC UK Charlie Reith, UK & Ireland government affairs, Expedia Group Felix Welckenbach, director organic growth and product, HomeToGo Siana Vesselinova, solutions consultant UK, PriceLabs Mike Mears, COO, VacayMyWay Kerry Leighton-Bailey, chief client and marketing officer, Feefo James Cassidy, senior director, partner success vacation rentals, EMEA, Expedia Group Kabiru Onikoyi, director, global services EMEA / APAC, 3Sixty Siddhi Mittal, co-founder, yhangry Why attend? Connect with peers from across the short-term rental industry during multiple networking opportunities. Learn from top creatives and executives during exclusive interview sessions and talks. Chart your path forward for 2024 and beyond based on your conversations and experiences at the Summit. Who should join? The short-term rental attendees are a mix of both experienced veterans and forward-thinking newcomers that seek greater insight into the future of this sector. Built for a business-operator audience, this event will bring together founders and executives from the vacation rental industry, venture-backed startups, online travel agencies, B2B vendors, and regulators in this ecosystem as both speakers and attendees, with an aim to push the conversation forward. Where is it? The Bankside Hotel, Autograph Collection, 2 Blackfriars Rd, Upper Ground, London SE1 9JU Agenda 08:00: Breakfast and networking 08:45: Welcome with IHM CEO Piers Brown 09:00: The State of the short-term rental market 09:10: Navigating the investment landscape 09:25: Preparing your business for a sale 10:00: Morning networking break 10:30: Debate: Over tourism vs under-tourism 11:00: Creating smarter regulation for everyone 11:30: AI debate - wary or excited for future? About the fund: The Greenwich Healthier Communities Fund is a new initiative that looks to prevent and respond to key health issues that affect communities in Greenwich by supporting new and existing community health initiatives. Established by the NHS Greenwich Charitable Funds, in partnership with the South East London NHS Integrated Care Board and the Healthier Greenwich Partnership, the fund will be managed by Groundwork London. Two Strands of funding are available so far, the Enabling Strand and the Delivery Strand. The different funding strands aim to support different kinds of work within Greenwich. Click here to visit our website to find out more about these Strands. This session will be focused on all funding strands available. We will run additional information sessions as and when new strands launch. About this event: This information session will discuss: Further details and eligibility for the Greenwich Healthier Communities Fund and the specific funding strands How to apply to the Fund, including what documents and resources are available Key programme dates of the Greenwich Healthier Communities Fund A Q&A session Please note: This is one of two identical sessions we are running about this fund. If you are already signed up to our other online application workshop , please don't sign up for this event as the content will be the same. Details will be sent to registered attendees in advance of the session.
